content: I show you my stuff with DM Scotty hey guys here's a miniature I used for
my game and I actually sculpted this miniature for my game in the AP I'm
playing I'm doing a modified kingmaker campaign which is actually a Pathfinder
module but I modify it from my 40 group so we are running through it there's an
encounter with this giant sham blur called chandrila 'kiss and I really
wasn't happy with any models dice that I've seen they just weren't big enough
now I want to show you how big this thing really is when I put a miniature
next to it so here is a standard miniature and look how giant that thing
is next to it I love it I love how group how how huge it is and no sham boys were
really nearly that big so let me talk about this a bit and I'll give you I'll
give you a kind of a closer look at it see some of the detail there now doing a
miniature can really seem daunting but you know it's like it depends what
you're doing humanoid type creatures can be really hard to sculpt unless you're a
professional sculptor animals are a little easier but stuff like this is
really really not that hard because there's really no frame of what you
don't you know they can't say oh the you know the nose is the wrong size or the
arms are too big or the lake you know because people can easily pick out when
something the scale of something is wrong so sculpting something like a
person or even a giant can be very daunting if you're not a good sculptor
doing an animal is a little easier and you know with fantastical animals you
can take a lot of liberties or creatures but with this kind of stuff which is
totally non-human it's really really really easy to sculpt it's really not
that hard to do this basically you know it's just it's just shapes I've just
rolled coils of clay mostly and just wrapped it around the different areas
the crew of the Beast and did some some tendrils coming off it and around the
mouth and some on the bottom so you know don't be totally intimidated by doing
things like you know aberrations or this kind of thing because it's it's it's
really not super difficult now I did sculpt this out of super sculpt Lee you
could use the epoxy clay that I've shown you before but the epoxy clay is much
more expensive and so I you know I just went the super sculpey route so what I'm
going to do is I'm going to show you the materials I used to make this critter
the first material I want to talk about is super sculpt Lee and I've shown this
before this is a great clay for doing projects like this it's not as expensive
as the epoxy not as hard to work with the epoxy can be very hard to work with
the great thing about super sculpt Lee is it doesn't dry until you bake it so
you can keep working on it until you're satisfied with the result with epoxy it
dries in a fairly short period of time so doing a large model like that can be
tricky you have to build it up in layers and all that kind of thing and be be a
fairly good sculptor but with this stuff you know it's really easy now there's
two different kinds of sculpey there's Skull Polly and super sculpt Lee I would
always use a super sculpey if you're going to if you're going to do anything
like this or even doing little things for your dungeon now you know super
sculpey can also be great for doing stuff for your dungeon you can do
furniture I've done wheels on carts like I showed on the over wagon I've done all
kinds of stuff with super sculpt Lee so with just a little bit of patience and
practice super sculpt it can be a great medium to work with now one problem I
had with the sculpture is the super sculpey is not strong enough for the
small areas of the sculpture like see the arms okay this would break off very
easily without support so what I've used is I'll show you here I've got some some
wire so this is a fairly thick wire that I got at the hardware store and I just
an armature out of this now I'm not going to go into building an
armature in this video if you're interested in in building an armature
just go online there's tons of there's tons of stuff online about how to build
an armature for a sculpture but yeah I just so basically I just use this wire
wrapped it up a little bit put some clay on it and bake that and then built the
rest of the model around that basic the armature that I did sorry so you know
the armature is really needed in something like this with long arms or
you know small areas if it's thicker you wouldn't really need the armature so
much but this kind of thing yeah I definitely needed the armature now I
also did an interesting thing with with texture on the critter and I'll see if
you can see really close here you can see it has some some texture on it and
what I did was I used my flexible modeling paste and I stippled it on okay
so basically you just dump or you just stick the brush into the paint get it on
the paint the paste on there and then when you put it on the model you just
dab it on like this okay and now that gives that neat that gives that nice
little texture and you can do that for a lot of other things too but that gives a
nice little texture on the model and just didn't make it look smooth so
without me having to sculpt all that little detail on there so that was a
really nice solution and quick solution to that so there you go there is a trick
tendr√° Lucas model that I did and you know don't be daunted by making your own
stuff your own miniatures like I said it goes from doing humanoid type things to
animals and fantastical creatures down to like total aberrations that you know
just really don't have any recognizable features as far as like scale or you
know relationship to each other so the aberration aberration type creatures can
be really easy and fun to make with a super sculpt Lee so I'll see you next
time on I show my stuff hey crafters I hope you've
enjoyed this episode of the dance craft make sure to subscribe and I have tons
of other videos as you can see I am the originator of the 2.5 D method of
crafting tiles I also do dirt cheap terrain for the table if all this
intrigues you make sure you check out all the videos below also join my forum
we have lots of great crafters on there who give advice I have a link above and
below and last but not least remember go forth and craft
you
